commit.message:
readme: update azure pipelines link

To point to `main` branch instead of `master`.

docs: refactor documentation into Sphinx documentation

README.rst was massive. Let's use Sphinx to document the package.

Minor changes to the docs were made as part of the refactor.

rust: implement ZstdCompressor::copy_stream()

test_compressor.py::TestCompressor_copy_stream now passes!

rust: implement ZstdCompressionObj

test_compressor.py::TestCompressor_compressobj now passes!

As part of this, we changed how the CCtx is stored in the compressor
so that we can share references to instances without having to share
Python object references, which necessitates implementing gc functions
on the Python types.

c-ext: use unified build for C extension sources

Fewer compiler invocations can reduce overhead and lead to more
compiler optimizations since all functions are in the same translation
unit.

But the real reason for this change is I want to switch to the single
file zstd distribution so things are simpler and presumably faster to
build. But this is blocked on
https://github.com/facebook/zstd/issues/2211.

c-ext: prefix WorkerState types with type

So we don't have duplicate type names in multiple source files.

c-ext: prefix WorkerError enums with type

So we don't have duplicate types declared in multiple source files.

c-ext: add #define guard to python-zstandard.h

This is a standard practice.

c-ext: prefix doc variable with type

So an identically named symbol is not defined in multiple source
files.

c-ext: prefix *DestBuffer types

So identical types are not defined in multiple source files.

c-ext: prefix C functions with type

So identically named functions are not defined in multiple source
files.

rust: implement ZstdCompressor.compress()

This doesn't implement 0-copy under the hood like the C code because
rust-cpython kinda limits us here.

rust: implement ZstdCompressor constructor

This required various changes throughout to hook up various APIs.

rust: define Rust types for arguments

This ensures type validation is done as part of function dispatch.

rust: fix level validation

This now matches the C implementation in terms of semantics

setup_zstd: remove `"zstd/" + p` calculations

When writing my previous patch, I was slightly slowed down identifying
what needed to be done because I first looked for a Makefile (doesn't
exist), then I looked briefly in setup.py, then I picked a random file
(zstd/compress/fse_compress.c) mentioned in the build output and grepped
for that string. When that still wasn't finding it, I descended into
zstd looking for a Makefile or similar, and still didn't find anything.

I forget what I eventually did that got me to the right place, but I'm
hoping that by pre-calculating this string modification, it can help
save someone even a small amount of time in the future.

setup_zstd: sort list of files/dirs

This is to make the linker produce reproducible .so files; otherwise the
order used when passing to the linker causes differences such as
ordering in the file and even file size.

Tested:
- Built once without this change, twice with this change, compared the
  md5sums of build/*/zstd.*.so for all three. "Without this change" was
  different from the two (identical) ones with this change applied.

rust: implement compression dictionaries

`test_train_dictionary.py` now passes with the Rust backend!

This required a change to the Rust zstd bindings to expose experimental
dictionary APIs, which is why the crate source changed to my private
fork. I've already submitted a PR and hopefully it gets incorporated.

rust: stub for ZstdCompressor

It doesn't do anything meaningful yet. But it is a start.

compressiondict: switch to fastcover for training

fastcover is the new training mechanism used by default. It appears the
old APIs are legacy and should be avoided.

This commit ports ``train_dictionary()`` to fastcover. As part of this,
we added arguments to control parameters exposed by the new mechanism.

Getting tests to pass was a pain. A problem was that different APIs have
different semantics. As part of the port, we consolidated onto calling
``ZDICT_optimizeTrainFromBuffer_fastCover()`` instead of 3 different
APIs. This ensures more consistency and is easier to debug. There will
likely be minor regressions in behavior as a result of this and other
changes. But the new state seems much better.

While this commit is annotated to KOLANICH, it was heavily refactored
by Gregory Szorc as part of incorporating the pull request. The CFFI
changes are all Gregory's. The original C code was highly refactored.

zstd: add debug messages for fastcover parameter errors

This can help diagnose opaque errors with values.

rust: implement compression parameters API

With this commit, test_data_structures.py passes using the Rust backend!

We had to switch to a Git revision of the zstd crates because the latest
released version doesn't properly support the `zstdmt` feature.

I'm not too crazy about the quality of the Rust code. It is mostly a
port of C semantics. We can refactor things later.

rust: implement frame parameters API

In order to do this we needed to define the ZstdError exception type.

`test_data_structures.py` tests for the added type and function now
pass.

rust: define module constants

With this, test_module_attributes.py passes!

zstandard: support a "rust" import policy

This will allow us to load the Rust-based extension module.

This appears to work. Although the extension defines nothing of value
so it is practically worthless. Although it is useful to be able to
load the extension.

setup: initial support for building Rust extension

In order to build Rust extensions we need custom distutils classes
for invoking `cargo build`. This commit establishes that support.

To make hacking on the Rust extension more friendly, we add setup.py
arguments to control the building of the different backends.

This is all somewhat hacky at the moment. But it is better than nothing.

The distutils code was inspired by what I wrote for the
oxidized_importer package.

rust: add Python module initializer boilerplate

It doesn't do much except define the docstring. But it is a start.

rust-ext: add stub for Rust library

Basically the output of `cargo init --lib` with minor customizations
for this project.

No integration with setup.py yet because there is no meaningful Rust
code.

ci: invoke pytest separately to use cffi backend

This fixes a long-standing issue where some tests didn't actually use
the cffi backend.

tests: remove make_cffi hack

This didn't actually work. A better solution is to run tests with
the environment variable set.
